et: Middle English {it}soun{/it}, from Anglo-French {it}son, sun{/it}, from Latin {it}sonus{/it}, from {it}sonare{/it} to sound; akin to Old English {it}swinn{/it} melody, Sanskrit {it}svanati{/it} it sounds
shortdef: a particular auditory impression : tone
the sensation perceived by the sense of hearing
mechanical radiant energy that is transmitted by longitudinal pressure waves in a material medium (such as air) and is the objective cause of hearing

dt: {bc}to order, signal, or indicate by a sound

dt.t: that {wi}sounds{/wi} a logical use of resources

pronounce
to put into words : voice

dt: {bc}exhibiting or based on thorough knowledge and experience

pt: {sc}healthy{/sc} {sc}sound{/sc} {sc}wholesome{/sc} {sc}robust{/sc} {sc}hale{/sc} {sc}well{/sc} mean enjoying or indicative of good health. {sc}healthy{/sc} implies full strength and vigor as well as freedom from signs of disease.
{sc}sound{/sc} emphasizes the absence of disease, weakness, or malfunction.
{sc}wholesome{/sc} implies appearance and behavior indicating soundness and balance.
{sc}robust{/sc} implies the opposite of all that is delicate or sickly.
{sc}hale{/sc} applies particularly to robustness in old age.

pt.t: still {it}hale{/it} at the age of eighty

pt: {sc}well{/sc} implies merely freedom from disease or illness.

pt.t: she has never been a {it}well{/it} person

pt: {sc}valid{/sc} {sc}sound{/sc} {sc}cogent{/sc} {sc}convincing{/sc} {sc}telling{/sc} mean having such force as to compel serious attention and usually acceptance. {sc}valid{/sc} implies being supported by objective truth or generally accepted authority.
{sc}sound{/sc} implies a basis of flawless reasoning or of solid grounds.

pt.t: a {it}sound{/it} proposal for reviving the economy

pt: {sc}cogent{/sc} may stress either weight of sound argument and evidence or lucidity of presentation.

pt.t: the prosecutor's {it}cogent{/it} summation won over the jury

pt: {sc}convincing{/sc} suggests a power to overcome doubt, opposition, or reluctance to accept.
{sc}telling{/sc} stresses an immediate and crucial effect striking at the heart of a matter.

et: Middle English, from Old English {it}gesund{/it}; akin to Old High German {it}gisunt{/it} healthy
shortdef: free from injury or disease
free from flaw, defect, or decay
solid, firm
to the full extent : thoroughly

dt: {bc}a long broad inlet of the ocean generally parallel to the coast
{bc}a long passage of water connecting two larger bodies (such as a sea with the ocean) or separating a mainland and an island

et: Middle English, from Old English {it}sund{/it} swimming, sea & Old Norse {it}sund{/it} swimming, strait; akin to Old English {it}swimman{/it} to swim
shortdef: a long broad inlet of the ocean generally parallel to the coast
a long passage of water connecting two larger bodies (such as a sea with the ocean) or separating a mainland and an island
the air bladder of a fish

{bc}to look into or investigate the possibility
used of a fish or whale

et: Middle English, from Middle French {it}sonder{/it}, from Old French {it}*sonde{/it} sounding line, probably from Old English or Middle English {it}sund-{/it} (as in Old English {it}sundlīne{/it} sounding line) from {it}sund{/it} sea
shortdef: to measure the depth of : fathom
to try to find out the views or intentions of : probe —often used with out
to explore or examine (a body cavity) with a sound

et: French {it}sonde{/it}, from Middle French, literally, sounding line
shortdef: an elongated instrument for exploring or sounding body cavities
son et lumière
